Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates earing festival wreath headdress with two lotus buds. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum?) coating with traces of pink paint and black eyes. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Three Naukratis examples in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology sport the same headdress and hair combination (NA656, NA655, NA654), for which there is a parallel in Athribis from a Roman context a 1st century BC context and a 2nd century AD context (Szymańska 2005, nos 64, 105, 115). This example looks later than the other two exampels (NA655, NA654). Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.086) (Phase 1)
